t: Proverbs 9
Wisdom versus Foolishness
Wisdom*pn has built her house; she*ln has carved out her seven pillars.
She*ln has prepared her meat; she has mixed her wine; she*ln has also set her table.
She*ln has sent out her female servants; she*ln calls out from the highest points of the city:
“Whoever*ln is inexperienced, enter here!” To*ln the one who lacks sense, she says,
“Come,*ln eat my bread, and*ln drink the wine I have mixed.
Leave*ln inexperience behind, and you will live; pursue*ln the way of understanding.
The*ln one who corrects a mocker will*ln bring abuse on himself; the*ln one who rebukes the wicked will get hurt.
Don’t*ln rebuke a mocker, or he will hate you; rebuke*ln the wise, and he will love you.
Instruct*ln the wise, and he will be wiser still; teach*ln the righteous, and he will learn more.
“The*pn fear of the Lord*s is the beginning of wisdom, and*ln the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
For*ln by me your days will be many, and*ln years will be added to your life.
If*ln you are wise, you are wise for your own benefit; if*ln you mock, you alone will bear the consequences.”
Folly*pn is a rowdy woman; she*ln is gullible and knows nothing.
She*ln sits by the doorway of her house, on*ln a seat at the highest point of the city,
calling*ln to those who pass by, who*ln go straight ahead on their paths:
“Whoever*ln is inexperienced, enter here!” To*ln the one who lacks sense, she says,
“Stolen*ln water is sweet, and*ln bread eaten secretly is tasty!”
But*ln he doesn’t know that the departed spirits are there, that*ln her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
